Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Patrick Dussault of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln is supported by the Chemical Synthesis program in the Division of Chemistry to conduct research related to new reactions of organic peroxides. The research focuses on two areas: 1) Mild methods to generate the first excited state of oxygen, often known as "singlet oxygen", through the chemical decomposition of readily available 1,1-dihydroperoxides; and, 2) Investigations of the new methods for formation of carbon-oxygen bonds based upon application of organic peroxides as electrophiles towards carbon-based nucleophiles.

This research may lead to much milder and more efficient methods for the rapid and/or large-scale generation of singlet oxygen, an important chemical oxidant which is also the power source for large-scale industrial and military lasers. The development of new methods for introduction of carbon-oxygen bonds is of great importance for industries and disciplines that need to prepare new organic molecules; this includes the pharmaceutical and agrochemical industries. Moreover, this project may enable the synthesis of classes of molecules not generally available at present, opening the doors to new technologies and yet unimagined classes of organic materials and polymers. The research will offer an outstanding opportunity for training of undergraduates and graduate students as future members of the nation's technical workforce. The training will be focused on organic chemistry (both experimental and literature components) but will also include strong components in teamwork, communication, mentoring, and research leadership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF grant CHE-1057982 included three major aims related to the chemistry of organic peroxides (highly reactive molecules containing an oxygen-oxygen bond).  Excellent progress was achieved within each aim and the body of results could have significant impact on the field and, in some cases, on society.

Specific Aim 1 investigated a new approach to the short-lived singlet excited state of oxygen. This useful reactant is traditionally prepared through energy-intensive photochemistry or through chemical decompositions requiring hydrogen peroxide and chlorine gas. Our preliminary work suggested that singlet oxygen could also be produced during fragmentations of derivatives of easily prepared 1,1-dihydroperoxides. We found the decomposition to be general to 1,1-dihydroperoxides as a class and to be achievable using a variety of activation conditions. Most importantly, the method furnishes singlet oxygen in yields superior to the best existing methods, and does so in organic solvents, maximizing the lifetime and utility of the short-lived oxidant. 

Specific Aim 2 greatly expanded the ability of chemists to prepare the ether (C-O-C) linkage, which is found in molecules ranging from fuels to antibiotics to anticancer drugs.  The synthesis of ethers has nearly always been achieved through reaction of an oxygen nucleophile (a species having excess electron density) with a carbon electrophile (a species deficient in electron density). A reversed approach, in which an electron-rich carbon nucleophile attacks the electrophilic O-O bond of peroxide, has remained limited by a paradox: those peroxides sufficiently electrophilic to be used for this reaction are rarely stable to the reaction conditions.  We explored the fundamental reactivity of peroxides and found a particular class, peroxyacetals, that achieve high reactivity without sacrificing stability. Our results will provide an important new tool for preparation of ethers difficult to access via traditional chemistry.

Specific Aim 3 successfully developed a new and safer approach to one of the most important bread-and-butter reactions of organic chemistry, the oxidative cleavage of carbon-carbon double bonds.  Ozone, which does an excellent job of cleaving carbon-carbon double bonds, is a remarkably "green" oxidant requiring only oxygen gas and electricity and furnishing only organic products and byproducts.  However, large-scale use remains limited by the formation of energy-rich peroxides that must be handled very carefully to avoid out-of-control decomposition reactions or even explosions. Our research investigated the ability of a simple chemical additive to sidetrack ozonolysis reactions away from formation of unstable intermediates and towards direct formation of thermally stable products. Our investigations revealed this goal could be accomplished using the simple additive pyridine and that the process involved a new class of peroxide fragmentation. Moreover, because the process generates only oxygen as a byproduct, the reaction solutions can be applied directly to further transformations without any purification or treatment. 

Overall, reserach supported by the grant resulted in eight publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals and a book chapter in a highly respected review series. One additional manuscript is under review and a second is in preparation. The research also resulted in a patent describing new methods for singlet oxygen production.  Training activities conducted as part of this grant have already resulted in with two PhDs and two M.S. degrees; at least two additional PhDs are anticipated based upon work initiated with this grant.  The funding has also been associated with research training of three undergraduate researchers.
